creator.organizationName: Coweeta Long Term Ecological Research Program

address.deliveryPoint: Daniel B. Warnell School of Forestry and Natural Resources

abstract.para: Data collected at climate station 77 at the Coweeta hydrologic lab. Includes :Monthly maximum air temperature (°C) , monthly minimum air temperature (°C) , monthly average air temperature (°C), monthly average daily relative humidity (%), monthly average daily vapor pressure (kPa), monthly average daily wind speed (m s-1) , monthly average daily photosynthetically active radiation (µmol m-2 s-1), from CS77 ‘open’ field measurements.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Overall bounding box describing the geographic region within the Coweeta LTER study domain represented in data set CWT_CLI_1106_006, based on the maximum geographic extents of all site polygons referenced in the data set

section.title: Air temperature and humidity
section.para: April 1992 through present: Air temperature is measured with a Vaisala model HMP45C relative humidity and temperature sensor and stored on Campbell CR10X data logger. Hourly means, maximums or minimums are calculated from 60 instantaneous measurements by the data logger. A Belfort hygrothermograph and thermometer setup described below is used as backup/quality control.

section.title: Vapor Pressure
section.para: Vapor pressure is calculated by the data logger from the recorded temperature and humidity values

section.title: Wind Speed
section.para: Wind speed is measured with a MetOne 014A anemometer

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: CWT Study Site WS27 -- Watershed 27 in the Coweeta Basin, North Carolina, USA. Hard Luck Creek Watershed. The first hydrologic records from this watershed date to 11/02/1946. The weir is a 120 degree V notch. This a control watershed, but it was partially defoliated by fall cankerworm infestations from 1972 to 1979.

section.title: Climate monitoring at Coweeta Hydrologic Lab
section.para: CLIMATE STATION LOCATION: Lat/long: 35°01’49.27/83°27’37.60 Elevation: 1398m Aspect: NE facing Date of First Record: 4/22/1992

DATA DESCRIPTION: Monthly maximum air temperature (°C) , monthly minimum air temperature (°C) , monthly average air temperature (°C), monthly average daily relative humidity (%), monthly average daily vapor pressure (kPa), monthly average daily wind speed (m s-1) , monthly average daily photosynthetically active radiation (µmol m-2 s-1), from CS77 ‘open’ field measurements.
Under forest canopy, measurements include air temperature, humidity, vapor pressure, soil and litter temperatures. Only ‘open’ field measurements are stored within an Oracle table.

April 1992 through present: Air temperature is measured with a Vaisala model HMP45C relative humidity and temperature sensor and stored on Campbell CR10X data logger. Hourly means, maximums or minimums are calculated from 60 instantaneous measurements by the data logger. A Belfort hygrothermograph and thermometer setup described below is used as backup/quality control. Vapor pressure is calculated by the data logger from the recorded temperature and humidity values. Wind speed is measured with a MetOne 014A anemometer. PAR is measured using LiCOR 190-SB.
Air temperature is measured continuously with a Belfort model 594 hygrothermograph using a 1-week chart. The instrument is housed in a National Weather Service louvered shelter. Maximum and minimum thermometers also are located in the shelter and are used as quality control checks for the hygrothermograph. Charts are replaced weekly. Maximum and minimum temperature for each day are recorded in degrees Fahrenheit and then converted to degrees Celsius.

abstract.para: Multi-scale process-oriented research is proposed on the consequences to the southernAppalachian socio-ecological system of the interaction between changing climate and landuse. Landscapes in the southeastern U.S. are expected to change profoundly in the next fivedecades as the socioeconomic factors driving the dramatic exurbanization of the past threedecades persist, and the changes to the rates, frequencies, and intensities of importantclimatic factors occur. Climate and land use change will especially impact the rural andquasi-rural lands that still characterize much of southern Appalachia where this research iscentered.The proposed research will extend long-term measurements, field experiments andinterdisciplinary modeling from small watershed studies to regional-scale analyses so as toaccount for increases in resource demand and competition from adjacent and more distantareas. The research focus will be on the provisioning service of water quantity, the regulatingservice of water quality, and the supporting service of maintaining biodiversity. Theoverarching question that guides this research is: How will key ecosystem processes and thefocal ecosystem services of water quantity, water quality, and biodiversity be impacted bythe: (1) transition in land uses from wildland to urban and peri-urban; (2) changes in climate;and (3) interactions between changes in land use and climate including both on-site and off-site feedbacks?

funding.para: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under grant numbers DEB-0823293, DEB-9632854 and DEB-0218001. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

description.para: Data file post-processing in the CWT-LTER Information Management Office

Under forest canopy, measurements include air temperature, humidity, vapor pressure, soil and litter temperatures. Only ‘open’ field measurements are stored within an Oracle table. Air temperature is measured continuously with a Belfort model 594 hygrothermograph using a 1-week chart. The instrument is housed in a National Weather Service louvered shelter. Maximum and minimum thermometers also are located in the shelter and are used as quality control checks for the hygrothermograph. Charts are replaced weekly. Maximum and minimum temperature for each day are recorded in degrees Fahrenheit and then converted to degrees Celsius.

otherEntity.entityDescription: Google Earth Keyhole Markup Language file describing the geographic locations sampled in data set knb-lter-cwt.1136.73

ns2:unit.name: microMolesPerSecondPerSquareMeter
ns2:unit.ns2:description: micro Moles (1E-06 moles of photons) per square meter (radiant flux)

ns2:unit.name: percent
ns2:unit.ns2:description: ratio of two quantities as percent composition (1:100)
